body: @markusweimer @jwang98052 Thanks for the reviews! I've addressed your comments, please have another look.
@anupam128 Looks good to me. Have you tested this with a real YARN cluster? If so I will test and merge.

Hi, @yunseong . Could you test this PR on your environment? I tested with reefrt/mesos0.25 on Docker on Mac. Docker machine VM has 4 cores CPU and 8GB RAM. The content of code might be discussed later.

```
Time: 474.528
OK (33 tests)
```

Hi, @markusweimer and @dafrista .  We concluded to use the given `injector` in #666 .
I didn't catch that the following MESOS runtime problem at that time.

```
Attempt to re-bind named parameter org.apache.reef.wake.remote.RemoteConfiguration$ManagerName.  Old value was [REEF_LAUNCHER] new value is [MESOS_EXECUTOR]
```

I think we can't use the given `injector`, so just go backward to the initial naive approach at #666. Of course, we have some time to decide how to fix this in a better way.
@bgchun @yunseong Thanks for your reviews! I've addressed your comments, please have another look.
@afchung Looks good. I will test and merge it.

Thanks @dongjoon-hyun! I'd like to test this on my docker, but I'm having hard time as I'm quite new to docker :) I'll try more and let you know once I check it works fine. I believe the result will be same as I also use Mac.

@markusweimer Could you take a look when you have time? Thanks!
This PR also passes the tests with #818 .
Oh, @yunseong . That seems like you faced failures on Ubuntu docker, right? I'll check that, too.

The use of a fresh Injector is indeed a bit wonky. If users need to bind additional configuration for anything in the `RemoteManager` dependency tree, we'll silently ignore it this way. This seems like an OK trade-off right now. At the same time, it will probably come up as a nasty issue in the future :)
The updated code (according to @markusweimer 's comments) also passed the MESOS integration tests on Docker on Mac.

@yunseong . I'm not sure what problem is bothering you , but is it about resource problem with `CloseEvaluatorTest`? Since the test requests 16 evaluators, so REEF fails to get `reef.jar.gz` from HDFS sometimes. In local-runtime environment, it only uses 4 evaluators.
@afchung  Yes I have run `HDInsightYarnClientTests` against an HDInsight cluster.
Can someone please review this?

@dongjoon-hyun The issues I'm experiencing are less related to REEF, but to Docker itself; I left my machine sleep during test on docker containers, and the containers did not respond any request except `ctrl+C` interrupt (even request to remove the containers). After reboot, I successfully created empty containers, but `./bin/runmesostests.sh` failed, saying 'permission denied to access /usr/bin'.
Is there any way to remove all existing containers, and restart with clean ones? It'd be very helpful if you let me know the solution :)

@dongjoon-hyun Also, for the `NUM_EVALUATORS`, does it cause problem all the time? The tests were running successfully at the initial time (before the failure I described above). 

Even we want to improve the stability, why don't we move that change to another PR as it seems out of scope for the issue?

Oh, in that case, I will rollback the last commit about the number of evaluators.

For docker, you can use the following commandline.

```
docker ps -a | grep -v ID | awk '{print $1}' | xargs docker rm -f
```

But, I recommend `Kitematic`. You can see the running machine visually and also you can browse the open ports, too. I think you already have `Kitematic` if you installed `Docker Toolbox`. :)
Hi, @yunseong , I removed the the last commit, too.

I did a pass. Minor comments.

One question: How do you plan on passing the credentials for the other hosts?

Looks good to me. 

@jwang98052 Can you merge?
Looks good to me. I will test and merge.

I thought the runtime will assume that client has ssh public keys for all remote nodes specified in `NodeListFilePath`. So there will be no need to pass the credentials. What do you think?
Other changes look Okay to me. @markusweimer Could you take another look? I'll test & merge this when you sign off.

It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
Are these tests completely useless, or maybe they should be renamed/moved to a project which contains the functionality they test?

I think the functionality that they test are covered by the Tang tests already. It is only copy-pasting lines of code from the Evaluator (which have already changed) and running tests on the checked-in files (where real format of the configuration file have also changed). So, essentially, this doesn't test anything more than Tang and Avro.

Sorry, I left a comment about JIRA issue #, but you already wrote this PR is not about `closing issue`. I delete the first comment. :)
This looks good to me. I will test and merge this. Thank you, @tcNickolas .
This looks good. I will test and merge.
Thank you!
Are we sure of this? They seem to test the deserialization of configurations in .NET which have been created on the Java side, right? Is that covered elsewhere?
It is covered in the REEF local runtime tests. In my opinion, I much prefer that than copying and pasting lines of Evaluator code.

Using a checked-in file to represent files generated via Java code is not good. If we change the code on the Java side, this will still not break the tests here if none of the C# data structure changed, since the `evaluator.conf` files are not automatically regenerated. The local runtime tests will be the first to fail in this case, so I think these tests are superfluous.
Ah, thanks, @afchung! In that case I agree, these should go.
I'll merge.
@jwang98052 I've force pushed to this branch, so I'll need to open a new PR for this. Thanks!
@jwang98052 Please have a look when you have time. This was originally #797. Thanks!

Thanks.
I'll merge this.
I'll merge this.

I've done the beginnings of a code review, but got confused: What is the problem addressed here? And, what part of it can't be solved via `org.apache.reef.client.parameters.DriverConfigurationProviders`?

The problem is that instead of providing specific runtime configuration for the submission handler I want to provide the hybrid configuration. I need to provide it instead of the current and not in addition to it.
Thanks, that makes sense. Is there a particular reason why you choose an interface, `DriverConfigurationProvider` over a configuration module, one per runtime?

For multi-runtime driver configuration provider will return a configuration with multi-runtime handlers and serialized configurations for all the runtimes we want to use. Using this kind of interface looks like a better option to me.
I'm done with a pass.
Uploaded new iteration
@anupam128 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!
I completed this pass.

@jwang98052 The tests should be covered by Local Runtime tests right? Since Local Runtime tests _actually_ generate the configurations on the fly. The test here would not break if you were to change any configurations on the Java side without regenerating the configuration.

Local run time indirectly test an evaluator.config that is true, but not all the flavors. Evaluator configuration can be set differently. We need test to cover all the cases. Local run time gives end to end result, while those tests allow me to debug step by step to see what elevalutor really gets from Java driver and how other objects at evaluator side are instantiated.
Evaluator is an executable and the only input is the evaluator.config. We should have some testing to run it directly, that would help for debugging when needed. We don't want evaluator.config to be hard coded , something created on the fly one would be nice. From this perspective, E2E testing is not a replacement of those tests. 
My point is we should improve and enhance those tests instead of removing.
Maybe we should revert this change and file a JIRA to update these tests? It will be harder to write them from scratch than to modify the input

I'm not convinced that two checked-in files cover too many cases either. The right solution is to write a Java executable that generates the files on the fly, have C# call into it, and deserialize the file.
Sure, these tests may help in debugging when the new config file breaks, but these tests do not actually _detect_ the break themselves (which is why we have tests in the first place), and are an afterthought to assist in debugging _when_ the build break gets caught by some other source (user or end-to-end), which in turn the newly generated files need to be checked-in to replace the old files. If the tests don't serve the purpose of catching the break, I believe they should be removed.

I agree, as I mentioned earlier, we should generate the config files on the fly and remove the hard coded evaluator.config. Once we set up this mechanism, we can then add more cases. 

Most tests are used to detect breaking changes, but that is not the sole purpose. Some tests show examples, some cover different scenarios so that we can also use them for debugging if anything is wrong, some even are used for repro purpose. We can put tests in different categories. For BVT tests, yes, they are for build verification purpose to check if anything is broken. I guess after we clean up all the tests, when we put tests for check in validation, we might only choose certain categories.

@dongjoon-hyun I've tried couple of times after removing the containers and merging this PR into current master. Now I'm struggling with new symptoms: All tests pass, but 4 Vortex tests (testVortexAddOne, testVortexAddOneCallback, testVortexExceptionCallback, testVortexTaskletCancellation) are failing due to timeout. (environment: Docker 1.10.0 on Mac OSX, 4-core CPU, 16GB Ram)

In the `driver.stderr`, I can see the following logs:

```
I0209 15:33:57.793793  4860 sched.cpp:641] Framework registered with a0880a5c-acf2-4d5c-af88-       3cc0a812e82c-0027
Feb 09, 2016 3:33:57 PM org.apache.reef.runtime.mesos.driver.REEFScheduler registered
INFO: Framework ID=value: "a0880a5c-acf2-4d5c-af88-3cc0a812e82c-0027"
 registration succeeded
Feb 09, 2016 3:38:50 PM org.apache.reef.runtime.common.driver.defaults.DefaultClientCloseHandler    onNext
WARNING: Received a close message from the client, but no handler was bound for it. Active threads:
  Thread 'org.apache.reef.wake.remote.impl.RemoteSenderStage-pool-6-thread-2':
    sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
    java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:186)
    java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.                          await(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2043)
    java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue.take(LinkedBlockingQueue.java:442)
    java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.getTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1068)
    java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1130)
    java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
    java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
    ...
```

It seems that the framework is registered in the Mesos master but does nothing for 5 minutes, which falls into timeout. In other Mesos tests, or YARN integration tests, I've never experienced such problem.

Do you have any clue about what would make the different results from yours?
@anupam128 I've added the parameter serializers, please have another look. Thanks!
@jwang98052 please have a look when you have time. Thanks!

Oh, you're back from holidays, @yunseong . 
Let me take a look again together. I've lost my context. :-)

Hmm. I rebased to the master and passed again. Also, `driver.stderr` doesn't contain any suspicious things. 

```
$ ./run-cluster.sh reefrt/mesos0.25
...
root@hnn-001-01:/reef/bin# ./runmesostests.sh hnn-001-01:5050
...
Time: 478.712
OK (33 tests)
```
I found that my docker version was different. It was 1.9.0. I'll upgrade my docker version and try again. :)

@dongjoon-hyun Thanks a lot for your help :) The version was 1.9.0 when the tests failed at the first time, and I reinstalled docker with 1.10.0 while trying to fix the containers, which were messed up. I'm not sure the version would be a problem, but it worths checking because the version is the only difference between mine and yours. I'll try 1.9.0 at my end. Again, thanks for your kind help!

Actually, on 1.10.0, all tests passed again for me.

```
...
Time: 476.968
OK (33 tests)
```

By the way, could you open Oracle VirtualBox and check the real VM memory? Is it really 16GB? It will cause memory thrashing since Macbook only has 16GB RAM physically.
@dongjoon-hyun Do you mean the "Base Memory" which I can see at the System tab? It shows 2048MB in my case.

Oh. Great. Right, that might be the root cause of your problem. That should be 8GB.
Please just increase that. :-)

On more thing, when you change your VM, you need to kill them.
After killing and adjusting it, I recommend you to restart your Mac and start 'Kitematic' first after rebooting. Good luck!

In the case that you want to use the "tests" for debugging, I believe we should at least use the `Evaluator` code there, but instead what we had in the file were copy-and-paste versions of `Evaluator` code that has fallen out of sync.

For the VM issue, we can reduce the minimum requirement VM memory by reducing some parameter in `Vortex` tests, but it's beyond the scope of this PR. 

After building some consensus in REEF community, I want to slim our testsuites, especially `Vortex` and `CloseEvaluatorTest`.
